awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Consequences of Climate-Induced Range Shifts on Multiple Ecosystem Functions
awd_abstract_narration:
The healthy functioning of natural ecosystems depends on the interactive roles of the various species that coexist in them. Different but closely related species replace each other along environmental gradients (e.g., from dry to wet). In some cases the new species function similarly, but in others species replacements have major impacts on the ecosystem and the goods and services provided to humans. Around the planet, species distributions are shifting in response to a changing climate, yet little is known about how the shifts will affect ecosystems.  One continuous study over the past 25 years of the animals that live in high elevation ponds in the Rocky Mountains of Colorado shows that species are shifting to higher elevations. And at the same elevation animals are moving to different types of ponds (permanent vs. temporary) as the water regime varies.  The goal of this new project is to determine how such shifts impact ecosystem function. Training of undergraduate students is a key component of the project and undergraduates will be involved with all aspects of the research. A cross-institutional research experiment will be developed for them, where they can work together to study the impacts of species range shifts from North Carolina to Maine. One graduate student and a postdoctoral associate will also be trained. Finally, the team will continue public outreach at each home institution, as well as at the Rocky Mountain Biological Laboratory in Colorado where most of the research will be conducted. 

This project will test how range shifts along environmental gradients in the dominant group of detritivores (caddisfly larvae) will affect multiple ecosystem processes, including the transfer of detrital energy to detritivore secondary production, release of detritus-bound nutrients for algal uptake, bottom-up effects of algae on herbivores, and ecosystem metabolism. Researchers will use models, experiments, and comparative data from whole ponds to investigate the degree to which 1) species replacements along permanence and elevational gradients are functional replacements in terms of detritus processing rates and cascading effects on brown (detrital) and green (algal) trophic paths, 2) the interactive effects of species shifts across the permanence gradient within an elevation and those associated with range shifts across elevations, and 3) how changes in ecosystem processes with community rearrangements scale up to natural ponds. Impacts will be assessed on three components: 1) the amounts of nutrients and energy from dead plant parts that are eaten by animals (detritivory), 2) how much of the consumption is released back into the environment and stimulates the growth of algae, which can then also be eaten, and 3) how new combinations of species affect the overall productivity of the ponds.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The functioning of natural ecosystems depends on the interactive roles of the various species that coexist in nature. However, species distributions around the planet are shifting in response to a changing climate, altering the identity and abundance of organisms in an ecosystem that perform important ecosystem functions. Our research with aquatic insects (e.g., caddisflies) in mountain wetlands showed the replacement of functionally important resident species by others from lower elevations can reduce the rate of an important ecosystem function: the breakdown and consumption of dead vegetation, which also influenced the release of nutrients that are used by organisms, such as algae, aquatic plants, and bacteria and fungi, that are the basis of most food webs and support animals such as amphibians and fish. However, analysis of 30 years of data showed that new species typically added to a community rather than replaced existing members, leading to remarkably resilient ecosystem functions.  We also developed statistical models that could anticipate these ecosystem changes by using information on the characteristics of different species including their diet, body size and life cycle duration. This approach combining species abundance with their characteristics is a promising tool for anticipating the outcome of climate-linked range shifts in other systems. However, our research also identified some challenges to making these predictions, as the outcome of range shifts also depended on the elevation of ponds, and the presence of predators or other small but abundant aquatic invertebrates that also consume dead vegetation. Thus, anticipating and managing the consequences of species range shifts also requires considering other members of the food webs into which organisms are moving. 

 

Our research has supported the career development of numerous scientists, including the promotion and tenure of two assistant professors to associate professors, and the training of three postdocs, two PhD students, and 20 undergraduate researchers. Each of these participants is now either furthering their academic careers as graduate students or postdocs, are faculty at academic institutions, or are employed in state and federal agencies and NGOs in the fields of biology, environmental science, and natural resource management. Our research has been communicated in 12 peer-reviewed scientific papers, conference presentations, public talks, public outreach and engagement, and incorporation of results in coursework and collaborative undergraduate research experiments at three different universities and one biological field station. We have also used our research to develop field-based learning activities that have engaged >1,000 grade 3-12 students from 28 different schools. 


 

 


Last Modified: 03/03/2023
Modified by: Brad W Taylor
